fields.name: Network Tools
fields.description: A collection of scripts to build and compare networks.

fields.name: Document Tools
fields.description: A collection of scripts to compare documents, tag documents for entities/keywords, and compute document statistics.

fields.name: Build Events From Files
fields.body:
An events file can be created from one or multiple text files by extracting entities found in each file using NER. It is assumed that all entities found in a file are spatially and temporally related.

How to Use:

  1. Upload all .txt or .docx you want to use.
  2. Choose a name for the output .csv events file.
  3. Click on Build
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .txt and .docx files.

Output File Format: A single .csv file.

Output Preview:

Event 1 Event 2 ... Event N
Entity 1 Entity 1 ... Entity 2
Entity 2 Entity 3 ... Entity 4
Entity 3 Entity 4 ... Entity 6

In this example, the input files could be named Event 1.txt, Event 2.docx, and Event N.txt. The names of the input files are used as event headers.

fields.name: Build Networks From Events
fields.body:
An event network refers to a network where nodes are linked by attending the same events. To build and event network you need to provide an events file which can be created manually or using the Build Events From Files tool.

How it Works:

  1. Each event file is separated by columns. Each column represents an event.
  2. Using the Python library networkx, an empty graph is created.
  3. Iterate through each column (event) from step 1
    • Pair each entity under current column with each other.
    • Iterate through these entity pairs and add each pair as an edge to the empty graph from step 2 using graph.add_edge(a,b).
    • Only unique edges are added. Therefore, if the same entity pair exists in other columns, they are ignored because their relationship is already accounted for.
  4. Build an adjacency matrix from the graph edges.
    • If there are N unique nodes in the graph from step 3, then create an N by N sized grid of zeros.
    • Iterate through each cell (row, col) of this grid and check whether the nodes at (row, col) are related--if they are, set the value of this cell to 1, otherwise to 0.
  5. Repeat step 1-4 for the remaining event files.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .csv event files.
  2. Choose a name for the output .zip file.
  3. Click on Build
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .csv event files.

Output File Format: A single .zip file containing all the .csv network files.

Output Preview:

Node 1 Node 2 ... Node N
Node 1 0 1 ... 1
Node 2 1 0 ... 0
... ... ... ... ...
Node N 1 0 ... 0

In this example, nodes are Node 1, Node 2, and Node N (with many other nodes possible). This matrix shows that Node 1 is related to both Node 2 and Node N, Node 2 is only related to Node 1, and Node N is only related to Node 1.

fields.name: Build Networks From Node Pairs
fields.body:
A network built from node pairs refers to a network where network edges are explicitly defined in a two-column .csv file. In this file, each row is a pair of nodes (network edge).

How it Works:

  1. Each node pairs file is separated by row. Each row represents a network edge.
  2. Using the Python library networkx, an empty graph is created.
  3. Iterate through each column (event) from step 1
    • Get the list of node pairs from step 1
    • Add all the edges in one go using graph.add_edges_from(list_of_edges).
    • Only unique edges are added.
  4. Build an adjacency matrix from the graph edges.
    • If there are N unique nodes in the graph from step 3, then create an N by N sized grid of zeros.
    • Iterate through each cell (row, col) of this grid and check whether the nodes at (row, col) are related--if they are, set the value of this cell to 1, otherwise to 0.
  5. Repeat step 1-4 for the remaining node pairs files.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .csv node pairs files.
  2. Choose a name for the output .zip file.
  3. Click on Build
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .csv event files.

Output File Format: A single .zip file containing all the .csv network files.

Output Preview:

Node 1 Node 2 ... Node N
Node 1 0 1 ... 1
Node 2 1 0 ... 0
... ... ... ... ...
Node N 1 0 ... 0

In this example, nodes are Node 1, Node 2, and Node N (with many other nodes possible). This matrix shows that Node 1 is related to both Node 2 and Node N, Node 2 is only related to Node 1, and Node N is only related to Node 1.

fields.name: Compare Networks
fields.body:
A network comparison consists of determining the node/edge overlap and unique nodes/edges between a pair of network files (adjacency matrices). These network files can be created manually or by using the Build Networks from Events/Node Piars tools.

How it Works:

  1. Files are collected from two different file-input fields and are differentiated by Networks A/B Label.
  2. Iterate through both lists of files from step 1, and pair those with the same filename.
    • It is essential that Networks A files come from one directory and Networks B Files from a different directory.
  3. Iterate through each pair of network files and load them into a networkx graph.
    • Store all the network edges in one set and all the network nodes in another set.
    • To get the nodes overlap between each network file pair perform an intersection between the nodes set of the first graph with the nodes set of the second graph.
    • In a similar manner, to get the edges overlap between each network file pair, perform an intersection between the edges set of the first graph with the edges set of the second graph.
    • To get the unique nodes of the first network perform a difference between the first networks' nodes set and the nodes set of the second network. To get the unique nodes of the second network, perform a difference between the second networks' nodes and the nodes of the first network.
    • Similarly, to get the unique edges of the first network perform a difference between the first networks' edges set and the edges set of the second network. To get the unique edges of the second network, perform a difference between the second networks' edges and the edges of the first network.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .csv network files for Networks A.
  2. Provide a unique label for Networks A files.
  3. Upload one or multiple .csv network files for Networks B from a different directory than Networks A.
  4. Provide a unique label for Networks B files.
  5. Choose a name for the output .zip file.
  6. Click on Compare
  7. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .csv network files.

Output File Formats: A single .zip file containing all the .csv network comparison files.

Output Preview:

Node Overlap Edge Overlap Unique Nodes A Unique Nodes B Unique Edges A Unique Edges B
A A and B C E C and D E and F
D H I C and H E and D
... ... ... ... ... ...

fields.name: Compare Documents
fields.body:
Documents can be compared in two ways: for content similarity and for textual similarity.

Content similarity is determined by using cosine similarity. Textual similarity is determined by using Jaccard similarity.

How it Works:

  • Cosine Similarity: A document can be mathematically represented by a vector comprised of features. These features are obtained from how often certain words appear and how important they are compared to other words -- this is called term-frequency-inverse-document-frequency (tf-idf). Once a document is turned into a features vector, vector math operations can be performed on it. In vector math, we can calculate how similar the directions of two vectors are by performing a dot-product between them.

    The dot-product is defined as a∙b = ∥a∥∥b∥cos(θ) which can be rearranged to be cos(θ) = (a∙b) / (∥a∥∥b∥)

    Cosine is a trigonometric function that varies from -1 to 1 with the angle θ (theta), where theta is the angle between two vectors. If two vectors point in the same direction, they are parallel and therefore the angle between them is 0, cos(0°) = +1 . If two vectors point in exactly the opposite direction, they are still parallel, however the angle between them is 180° and cos(180°) = -1. Finally, if two vectors are perpendicular to each other, the angle between them is 90° and cos(90°) = 0. Since we're dealing with vectors derived from word features, we can calculate the cosine of the angle between them to determine if they point in the same direction (+1), in maximally opposite direction (-1), in unrelated directions (0), or anywhere in between. If two feature vectors point in the same direction, then the documents are likely talking about the same topic. If their directions are maximally opposite then the documents are talking about maximally opposite topics. If their directions are perpendicular, they are talking about different topics altogether.

  • Jaccard Similarity: is used to detect whether two documents are almost identical. This method reduces a document to a set of strings through a process called shingling. Shingling extracts the set of all substrings of length k (k-shingles) from a text. This is implemented by sliding a window of size k over each document--character by character--and putting the substrings into a set. For example, the document "abcabcac" yields the 3 shingles {"abc", "bca", "cab", "cac"}. This set eliminates duplicate shingles.

    Once documents have been turned into shingle sets, the jaccard similarity of 2 sets (2 documents) is calculated by dividing the size of the intersection of two sets by the size of their union. In other words, the ratio of the number of words that are found in BOTH documents and the total number of unique words in BOTH documents.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .txt or .docx files.
  2. Choose an output .csv name without the file extension.
  3. Click on Compare
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .txt or .docx files.

Output File Formats: A single .csv file containing all the document comparisons.

Output Preview:

File A File B Cosine Similarity Jaccard Similarity
file1.txt file2.txt 0.4 0.1
file1.txt file3.docx 0.5 0.8
file2.txt file3.docx 0.23 0.12

fields.name: Tag Documents for Keywords
fields.body:
One or multiple documents can be tagged for a list of keywords.

How it Works:

  1. The content of each document is modified to exclude trailing spaces and turned to lower-case.
  2. Each keyword in the user-provided list of keywords is turned to lower-case.
  3. Iterate through each keyword and check if it exists in the document's content.
  4. Add a list of found keywords to the header of the tagged documents.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .txt or .docx files.
  2. Manually enter a list of keywords separated by commas.
  3. Choose an output .zip name without the file extension. This file will contain all tagged documents.
  4. Click on Tag
  5. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .txt or .docx files.

Output File Formats: A single .zip file containing all the tagged documents.

Output Preview:

The following excerpt was generated by providing the list of keywords: education, fracking, and enterprise.

Found Keywords: EDUCATION, FRACKING, ENTERPRISE

114th Assembly candidates on education, fracking, same-sex marriage October 10, 2012

By CHRIS MORRIS - Staff Writer (),Adirondack Daily Enterprise With less than a month to go before Election Day, Dan Stec and Dennis Tarantino continue to make their pitch to voters in New York's new 114th Assembly District.The candidates squared off in a debate last month in Queensbury, and since then they've been campaigning nonstop, meeting with local elected officials and making the rounds at community events throughout the district.Each candidate received two endorsements last week. Stec picked up support from the National Rifle Association and the National Federation of Independent Business. NFIB's New York state director, Mike Durant, said in a press release that Stec "has demonstrated the strongest support for the small business agenda."Article PhotosDennis Tarantino and Dan Stec debate Sept. 25 in Queensbury. (Enterprise photos Chris Morris)Tarantino received backing from two unions: the Service Employees International Union Local 200 United and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union 910.---EducationFact BoxNew York's new 114th Assembly District includes all of Essex and Warren counties as well as the northern parts of Saratoga and Washington counties. The district is currently the 113th and has been represented by Assemblywoman Teresa Sayward, R-Willsboro, since 2003. Sayward will retire at year's end to spend more time with her family.

fields.name: Tag Documents Using Stanford's Named Entity Recognizer (NER)
fields.body:
One or multiple documents can be tagged for named entities using Stanford's Named Entity Recognizer. These entities can be person, location, organization, money, percent, time, and date.

How it Works:

  1. The content of each document is inputted into NER.
  2. NER outputs text with tagged named entities.
  3. NER struggles to group "first_name-last_name" groups together, so we iterate through the tags to combine consecutive named entity tags.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .txt or .docx files.
  2. Choose an output .zip name without the file extension. This file will contain all NER tagged documents.
  3. Click on Tag
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .txt or .docx files.

Output File Formats: A single .zip file containing all the NER tagged documents.

Output Preview:

In bringing his distinct vision to the Western genre, writer-director 

<PERSON>
Jim Jarmusch
</PERSON>
has created a quasi-mystical avant-garde drama that remains a deeply spiritual viewing experience. After losing his parents and fiancée, a 
<LOCATION>
Cleveland
</LOCATION>
accountant named 
<PERSON>
William Blake
</PERSON>
(a remarkable 
<PERSON>
Johnny Depp
</PERSON>
) spends all his money and takes a train to the frontier town of Machine in order to work at a factory. Upon arriving in Machine, he is denied his expected job and finds himself a fugitive after murdering a man in self-defense. Wounded and helpless, 
<PERSON>
Blake
</PERSON>
is befriended by Nobody (
<PERSON>
Gary Farmer
</PERSON>
), a wandering Native American who considers him to be a ghostly manifestation of the famous poet. Nobody aids <PERSON>Blake</PERSON> in his flight from three bumbling bounty hunters, preparing him for his final journey--a return to the world of the spirits.

fields.name: Compute Document Statistics
fields.body:
You can compute document statistics for one or multiple .txt and .docx files. These statistics include document word count, reading level (Flesch Kinkaid), keyword frequency, and sentiment analysis.

How it Works:

  1. Iterate through each document and remove trailing spaces.
  2. To calculate the word count, separate each document by whitespace and count the words.
  3. To calculate reading level for a document, we use the following formula 
          
        Reading Level = 0.39*(total_words / total_sentences) + 11.8*(total_syllables / total_words) - 15.59
  4. Keyword frequency is calculated by counting the number of times a keyword in a user-provided keyword list appears in a document.
  5. Sentiment analysis is calculated by using Python's textblob library. This analysis includes the following measures
    • Polarity: a number between -1 and +1. A polarity greater than 0 represents a document that has a positive tone and a polarity less than 0 has a negative tone.
    • Subjectivity: a number between 0 and +1. A subjectivity that is closer to 0 represents a document that is objective, while a subjectivity closer to +1 represents a document that is mostly subjective.
    • Classification: can be pos or neg. This represents the overall classification of a document's tone. It can either be positive or negative.

How to Use:

  1. Upload one or multiple .txt or .docx files.
  2. Choose an output .csv name without the file extension. This file will contain all results.
  3. Click on Compute
  4. Your file will start downloading shortly. Be patient and don't refresh the page.

Accepted File Formats: One or multiple .txt or .docx files.

Output File Formats: A single .zip file containing all the NER tagged documents.

Output Preview:

Using the file 114th Assembly candidates 20121010.docx and the keywords list [The, This, That, Of] as an example, the output of this tool looks like this

File Name Reading Level The This That Of Polarity Subjectivity Classification P_POS P_NEG
10.8 843 23 15 55 3 0.1449 0.863 pos 1 0
